185980642.review:
I tried to enjoy this game, and there was something there, but it's really hard to see.
The inability to adjust the UI more precisely hurts it greatly from just a usability standpoint. 
Attempts to adjust the UI leaves various elements dislodged and unable to place in position without resetting everything.
The game fails to fit higher resolutions, and becomes both unreadable and dysfunctional, even after adjustments.
The map is a failure, often with objectives spilling past or beneath the borders. 
The fidelity is no issue, but when the "update" has to wondering whether or not it came before or after, that's just a problem.
Can't resize Inventory, and the starter UI buttons on the main tool bar is a garbagefire. Nothing reads well, and the flow of it is like rolling a boulder up a mountain in the middle of a river running the other way.
Buffs & Debuffs are so tiny it frequently goes unnoticed.
And many other nitpicks.

Simply put, this game needs a massive refresh for the UI, UX, and a more defined Graphical update in line with the spirit of the universe. Right now, it's fine to play if you can get over the glaring issues, but I don't have sunscreen strong enough for these blinding problems.

I want to enjoy this game, because there's plenty to, but the dated interaction between Player and Game is just too much. It's not an age issue either - Guild Wars 1 and City of Heroes have made do. This game just needs some care for the fundamentals, otherwise it'll just keep pushing peopleaway - great IP or no.

185920125.review:
Lotro is a clunky, very dated MMO - BUT if you play MMOs for the adventure and for the community, this is the one. 

The world is massive, and it *feels* like a fleshed out world rather than just some theme park. The story quests are engaging, exploring is fun and rewarding (and not in a 'ticking off a checklist' kinda way, but in a 'whoa that place is cool' kinda way), and it feels true to the spirit of Tolkien's legendarium. The game doesn't try to rush you to endgame, instead letting you enjoy exploring middle-earth on your long and epic quests. However, if you do care about raiding or pvp, you're probably better off playing a more modern MMO. There's some of that here, but its not the game's strongest suit.

The people you'll meet are just lovely. People are actually friendly and kind to their fellows, even when grouping with randoms, and there's a lot of patience for people who are learning the game. There's this vibe that most people aren't in a rush, we're all just taking our time and smelling the pipeweed. At least thats my experience on Gladden, I haven't played the other servers.

I stopped playing the game a few years ago, after the world mobs started getting a bit too easy. I felt the sense of danger was gone, which made questing across middle earth feel less like an adventure and more like a grind. However, I recently found out that a difficulty system was implemented for the world questing. You can turn up the difficulty for just yourself so you can go back to getting unceremoniously murdered by packs of wolves because you messed up your gambits, just as Eru intended. Very cool stuff!

As a huge Tolkien fan, I can also say this game mostly fits in with the lore. You can't be too strict on it as it is after all an MMO, so there are certain things that don't fit. For instance, the window of time in which the story quests had to have happened is dubiously small for how much you're getting done. There are two magic-user classes (lore-master which uses elf-lore to do things like set kindling on fire or heal fellows, and rune-keeper which uses the power of words to zap people or heal them), and while they made some effort to make these work lore-wise, its obviously quite iffy, especially for non-elves. Rune-Keeper is super fun though.

However, aside from that, there are plenty of creatures and characters who don't appear in the books, but who feel right at home in Tolkien's world. The designers clearly love Lord of the Rings, and they have a lot of fun with exploring the less fleshed out parts of the legendarium - such as what Nameless Things dwell in the pits of Moria? Who is the Mouth of Sauron? How did Durin VII renew the former glory of the dwarves? etc. There's also plenty of stuff that is in the books, including the big battles like Helm's Deep and Minas Tirith. You can even join the Grey Company and travel the path of Dunharrow with Aragorn. So lots to love here for lord of the rings fans.

Overall, if you're into lord of the rings and/or you enjoy the social, story, and exploration aspects of MMOs more than endgame, you need to play this game !

185798798.review:
Game seems nice, but the UI is dated and it's quite difficult to figure out things as a new player. 

For example, an early side quest is to find Bilberries for a tea. The NPC doesn't tell you where these might be found, nor does a quest marker indicate where to look. I assume we're meant to wander around in search of them, which I did but never found them. 

I'm all for discovery in games, but you've got to give a new player at least a cardinal direction. 


Couple that with the game throwing too many abilities at you for you to properly understand in the early game (I was a minstel) and it gets overwhelming very fast. 

Wanted to like the game.

185703920.review:
As one of the longest-running MMORPGs on the market, The Lord of the Rings Online remains a fascinating journey into Middle-earth. Since its launch in 2007, it has provided players with an opportunity to walk the paths of Frodo, Aragorn, and the Fellowship. In 2025, LOTRO is both a testament to the enduring power of Tolkien’s world and an example of the challenges of keeping an aging MMORPG relevant. Here’s a breakdown of its strengths and weaknesses across key categories:

Story: A Tolkien Lover’s Dream
Rating: 9/10

LOTRO’s storytelling is its crown jewel. From the sprawling epic quests that run parallel to the events of The Lord of the Rings to the rich side stories that delve into the history and culture of Middle-earth, the game offers a narrative experience unmatched by most MMORPGs. Whether you’re helping Aragorn reclaim his heritage or assisting a local farmer in the Shire, the writing feels authentic and deeply rooted in Tolkien’s lore.

The world-building is meticulous, and every region—from the rolling hills of the Shire to the haunting plains of Angmar—feels alive with history. For fans of Tolkien, LOTRO is a love letter to Middle-earth, and its ability to immerse players in the world is second to none.

However, the pacing can feel slow, especially for newer players unused to the game’s leisurely approach to storytelling. Some quests still rely on dated “fetch-and-kill” mechanics, but the richness of the narrative makes up for these shortcomings.

Graphics: Ugly but Charming
Rating: 5/10

LOTRO’s graphics are, to put it kindly, a relic of a bygone era. While the game’s art direction strives to capture the beauty of Middle-earth, the execution falls short by modern standards. Character models are stiff, textures are blurry, and the environments, while artistically ambitious, lack the technical polish of contemporary games.

That said, there’s a certain charm to LOTRO’s aesthetic. The landscapes, particularly in regions like Rohan or Rivendell, can still evoke awe if you squint past the technical limitations. The game’s lighting and skyboxes occasionally deliver moments of surprising beauty, but overall, LOTRO struggles to compete visually with even mid-tier games in 2025.

Gameplay: Dated but Functional
Rating: 6/10

LOTRO’s gameplay shows its age, with combat and movement mechanics that feel clunky and sluggish compared to modern MMORPGs. The tab-targeting system and dated UI can be off-putting to new players, and long-time veterans have likely grown accustomed to the quirks more out of habit than preference.

However, the game compensates for its mechanical shortcomings with depth. The class system is diverse, offering unique playstyles, and the crafting and housing systems are robust for those who enjoy these aspects of MMORPGs. Skirmishes and instances provide group content, but the mechanics feel basic compared to the dynamic encounters seen in newer games.

A major boon is the tireless effort of the small development team, which consistently releases updates to improve quality of life, add content, and address community concerns. While the gameplay isn’t revolutionary, the love and care put into maintaining it are evident.


Community: The Beating Heart of the Game
Rating: 10/10

LOTRO’s community is one of the most welcoming and passionate you’ll find in any MMORPG. From in-game role-playing groups to large-scale concerts hosted by player bands, the community consistently breathes life into Middle-earth. If you’re a fan of cooperative gameplay or social interactions, LOTRO delivers in spades.

Players are eager to help newcomers, and there’s a strong sense of camaraderie among fans of Tolkien’s work. The game fosters an environment that feels more like a fellowship than a collection of strangers. If anything, the community is the reason many players stick with the game despite its technical flaws.


Technical Performance: A Major Drawback
Rating: 4/10

LOTRO’s technical issues are its Achilles’ heel. The 32-bit servers suffer from horrendous lag and frequent crashes, particularly in densely populated areas or during major in-game events. These performance problems are a constant source of frustration and mar an otherwise immersive experience.

The upcoming 64-bit servers are a beacon of hope for the future, promising smoother performance and addressing many of the long-standing issues. However, until they are fully implemented and optimized, LOTRO’s technical struggles remain a significant barrier for both new and returning players.

Sound: A Middle-earth Symphony
Rating: 8/10

LOTRO’s sound design is a highlight. The music, composed by Chance Thomas and others, captures the spirit of Middle-earth beautifully. From the tranquil melodies of the Shire to the stirring battle themes of Mordor, the soundtrack adds depth and emotion to the game.

Voice acting is sparse, but where it exists, it’s serviceable. Environmental sound effects, like the rustle of leaves or the distant call of an eagle, enhance the sense of immersion. While not perfect, the audio design is one of the game’s more polished aspects.


Verdict: A Flawed but Endearing Journey
Overall Rating: 7/10

The Lord of the Rings Online in 2025 is a mixed bag. It’s a game of contrasts: breathtaking storytelling marred by dated gameplay, a magnificent community hindered by technical shortcomings, and a world full of charm that struggles under the weight of its aging infrastructure.

For Tolkien fans, LOTRO remains a must-play. A one-month VIP subscription is enough to experience the highlights—exploring iconic locations, delving into the epic storylines, and soaking in the community’s creativity. However, it’s hard to recommend as a long-term investment unless you’re deeply committed to Middle-earth and willing to overlook the game’s numerous flaws. It’s a journey worth taking for the love of Tolkien’s world, but not without its bumps along the road.

185669684.review:
Seemingly the developer doesn't want any new players anymore. I played many MMO's and nowhere was it this difficult to install and run a game...

It starts of with the installation that had to be restarted multiple times, since it got stuck. After several HOURS it finished the installation. You then have to create a new account in order to play, no problem. Or so I thought. The link to their website wasn't working, the site wouldn't even load. Again, after several tries it loaded. And now comes the part that made me quit the whole thing: Account creation. Boy how bad could it be?

First account name. Fair enough. Then your password. For this you have to check several requirements. It has to be between 8-16 characters long, it has to contain a letter and a number and it only allows for letters, numerical values and special characters. It doesn't give you the opportunity to create your own password if it doesn't follow these restrictive rules.
And then my favorite part: Your birth date! But nothing you click in the list works. It always says "Please enter a valid birth date". So all birth dates are invalid and you cannot create an account. And this was the final straw. How hard can it be to make an account? How about impossible?

Edit: And when you finally can create an account, you will be searching hours for a valid name for your character! I tried random combinations and strangely not a single one was valid. Guess you have to name your human "FancyPants263" for 1-262 are already taken... Fuck this.

I don't waste any more time on this.

185547053.review: I've been playing this game since late 2011 and when I say this game has had an impact on my life I mean it. The community is much smaller than it once was, and the funding isn't what it used to be, but having a fully interactive recreation of Middle Earth is something that we may never see again in video game form. 185524204.review:
This is an amazing game marred by a developer who doesn't know how to make a functional account system. It's next to impossible to log into the game because my password only ever works once and changing it takes HOURS to get the systems to work. Then the game tries to update on launch every time and instead manages to corrupt data files that take 60 seconds to "recheck" instead of *fixing* the issue. Great game, don't play it unless the developers learn to get themselves together and make the backend non-game stuff work properly.

By the way, it's actually worse because when you reset your password your account becomes inaccessible because the new password hasn't applied but the old password, if you remember it, also doesn't work anymore. Great work Standing Stone Games, find a new day job and let someone else who knows what they're doing make this system.

I'll update this review IF the developers ever fix these issues, since they're issues that shouldn't even be possible for an MMO developed by anyone who has ever made an account system or update system.

EDIT: I just made a new account because that worked for some reason and DIDN'T take 6 years so. Just don't ever change your password!

185206705.review:
It's crazy how much I regret not playing this earlier...

This game has been around for a looong time, although I always saw it as an expensive game, due to the amount of the expansions. But, they made it a way that you can get access to many aditional quests and expansions through a unique  in-game system (which is totally F2P).

This is a completely different game among the gender, they really made it a RPG more then anything. The game doesn't start in the "endgame", instead, every tiny peace of its progression and quest-lines are super captivating, the landscapes, dialogs all the enviroment is hand crafted and masterpieces. Even in the side quests, which most games uses as a way to grind up your level and keep up with the main storyline power requirements, is completely different. Every village, city or region that you are, you will feel the impact of the major events on Middle Earth and how they affect the people, and you will be compelled to help them and inmerse in this wonderfull game.

This is a love gift for every Tolkien reader.

185180534.review:
Graphismes réalistes. Quêtes principales pleines d'actions et surprenantes. 
Certaines quêtes annexes sont marrantes mais la plupart sont inutiles, mais que voulez-vous, ce sont des quêtes annexes. 
Se balader sur la Terre du Milieu comme on veut et faire ce que l'on veut, c'est super cool. Tous les lieux des livres et des films s'y trouvent même s'il faut parfois acheter des extensions et ils sont très bien réalisés. Communautés très sympathique. Très bonne ambiance avec les évents, escarmouches etc.. 
La possibilité d'avoir plusieurs tenues, de jouer de la musique, etc.. vous offre une liberté infinie dans le jeu. Je recommande LOTRO pas seulement aux fans de LSDA, mais à tous ceux qui aiment le fantastique.

For the purely free to play aspect (there is a VIP membership, similar to other MMOs) the game has a few annoying things such as the lack of storage. This can become a pain with crafting and I'm sure there's more getting into the higher levels. You can buy more storage out right for a not so crazy amount of money (compared to newer money hungry games). The other option is to become a VIP member and automatically get more. So far, I'm hooked and I'm pretty sure I'll be subscribing as a VIP member for the discounted yearly rate once I dive even deeper.

184754831.review:
Such a great MMO. I've played almost all the big names in the genre, and LOTRO truly stands out as something unique. As a huge Tolkien and LOTR fan, I've been having an absolute blast as a new player. The world-building is fantastic, and the storytelling stays faithful to the source material, which makes it even more enjoyable. The game does look a bit dated (which gives it a charming old-school vibe that I personally like), and the UI is for ants on 1440p. Despite all these quirks, LOTRO is a blessing for anyone who loves Middle-earth. The community in this game is amazing—players are very friendly and always willing to help.

One of the best recent changes is the introduction of "legendary servers." These servers not only solve the game's server lag issues but also offer a progression system similar to WoW Classic. I decided to start on a legendary server, and it was hands down the best choice I could have made as a new player. Experiencing each expansion slowly, as if they're launching for the first time, has been so fun. When I first tried the game in 2019, I was overwhelmed by the level cap and the sheer amount of content. This time, the legendary server has made the experience feel much more approachable and fun. I've been enjoying my LOTRO adventure so much that I couldn't even stop playing during my holiday break lol.

Overall, I believe this game will remain one of my favorite MMOs. For anyone who loves Middle-earth or appreciates MMOs with deep storytelling and community, LOTRO is an absolute must-play.

184685062.review:
[h3] The atmosphere is truly wonderful, a real throwback to the golden era of MMOs from around 2005. [/h3] I wish we would get more MMORPGs in this old school style with exactly these vibes, but with modern UI - since I wanted to carve my eyes out after trying to figure out what is written on my screen either at 1080p (in 4k the nightmare only intensified).
[b]Devs, it is really such an issue to redesign UI to make it properly readable and eye-pleasant? Heck guys, it is the only reason I won't continue playing despite giving it an angry upvote.[/b]

184428388.review:
PLayed this game a few days back and tbf its a very nice MMO. I do love the world, mechanics, questing all that, but as soon as my inventory got filled with those chests you can unlock needing a key, which in return you can get with irl currency in the shop, i was done for it. 
Surely you get those coins for completing task aswell but imo you can clearly see the hidden greed making money here. I wouldnt mind if those chest would have dropped rarely and become some sort of reward thing in the open world, but after an evening playing 10 slots of my inv were taken by those chests. A big downsight for me in mmo's or rpgs in general is when you get cool stuff for money instead of working for it. Another thing which started to bother me was the typical f2p exp scroll here, comfort item there thingi which also fill your inventory almost every day. Surely you can remove those if you dont like it or just use em, but throwing away a rather decent XP buff is still stupid. I dont understand why giving a player those things in he first place. For me this just ruined the game and made this actually pretty game feel like the typical bad build f2p mmo from eastern countries due to its systems (Having a mount tied to one char only, but pay more for it to be account wide. Buy a cheap mount but its still slower than the slightly more expensive one. This may not apply to ppl who play this game for longer and have gotten ingame mounts alrdy which also have a 68% speed buff, but new players dont). Please dont get me wrong here. You, who might reads this and enjoys the game to its core; I'm really happy for you and I understand you. This is just an impression of a literaly new player to this game.
Surely i have to admit that since this is f2p the devs need/want to have a way to make money. But in lotro it just feels awkward.
Another thing which was limiting my playtime experience was the bad UI. Caught myself a few times wondering where i can find certain stuff. For me this is just bad navigation and is fairly outdated. Especially an UI should be one of the things devs should consider to build as good as possible. New players may get overwhelmed by it and become frustrated by the design etc.
One more thing which insanley limited the fun i had playing was the bad server performance. God damn... sometimes waiting 20 seconds for the server to catch up again and leaving my freeze state. Yes, they do have vip servers which you can enter by paying the typical monthly sub price, but even these have smaller hickups from time to time. they are by far not as bad but its still sad. There is not a single MMO i play/ played so far which has similar server issues. (Also, Why have a "strong" f2p shop monetisation and gameplay elements when having this monthly pay system.. dont get it)

So, Great game but feels weird at some points :)
For people who want to dive into this world and just enjoy it I do recommend this game. Graphics may be outdated but have their own charm and detail which I liked a lot to be honest. It feels oldschool in a good way.

Wer über 30 ist und einen entspannten Abend verbringen will und lieber auch mal Blumen pflückt statt die Maus bei CoD vollzuschwitzen, der wird Lotro lieben. Die Community ist auch super nett und überhaupt nicht toxisch!

184101461.review: A slower paced, story-forward MMO with dated graphics that somehow still manages to impress.  I've spent a lot of time in Middle Earth and it's a lovely place to be.  The cash shop items have improved somewhat, but I recommend trying it out.  Go VIP if you are able for the maximum benefit.

184101302.review: Been playing this game since I was a wee lad. It has a special place in my heart. I think it has been over 12 years. This game is really fun to play by yourself and they have come a long way since I was pre-teen. This game has used the magic of LOTRs to make a game that fits the atmosphere and the world the books/movies built. It give you your hankering for more LOTRs content. Instead of watching Rings of Power on Amazon. play this game instead because it will give you better back story than any LOTRs TV show would. One of, if not, the best Lord of the Rings games there is to date.

184008487.review: LOTRO is the very best adaptation of the LOTR series every made.  It is a faithful, loving tribute to Tolkien's works, and its beautifully-crafted world--both in a visual and storyline sense--offers up tons to praise.  I especially recommend playing for the game's RP and music communities.  The best MMO out  there, even more so if you like LOTR.

183984977.review: Einfach ein Muss für jeden HdR Fan. Ich bin kein Online Rollenspieler, spiele sonst auch keine, aber dieses eine Spiel hat es mir von Anfang an angetan. Ursprünglich noch für mehrere Spieler gedacht, hat sich das Spiel inzwischen für Singleplayer mehr als nur tauglich entwickelt. Ich liebe es, durch die verschiedenen Regionen zu reisen, die Quests sind teilweise anspruchsvoll, teilweise humorvoll und manchmal wiederholt sich eine Aufgabe auch nur. Allerdings tut dies dem Spiel keinen Abbruch. Ich werde jedenfalls noch etliche Stunden damit verbringen.

183966473.review:
Old Tom Bombadil is a merry fellow
Bright blue his jacket is and his boots are yellow
Reeds by the shady pool, lilies on the water
Old Tom Bombadil and the river-daughter


Tom Bombadil aside, its refreshing to see such an old and beloved mmorpg still getting content and expansions. The engine is getting pretty old, almost coming up on 20 years, but they still continue to expand and put out content, while they do have a cash shop that doesn't seem to be their focus and that's a welcomed change in todays mmo landscape.
